multiblock.error.biggerreactors.no_termi: Reactors require at least one terminal
multiblock.error.biggerreactors.no_rods: Reactors must have at least one fuel element
multiblock.error.biggerreactors.control_: Control rods can only be placed on the top of the reactor (%d, %d, %d)
multiblock.error.biggerreactors.fuel_rod: All fuel elements must extend from top of the reactor to the bottom (%d, %d, %d)
multiblock.error.biggerreactors.no_contr: All fuel elements must be topped with a control rod (%d, %d)
multiblock.error.biggerreactors.dangling: There appears to be another reactor inside this one, is something wrong? (%d, %d, %d)
tooltip.biggerreactors.buttons.reactor.a:
§bDeactivate Reactor
Residual heat will still generate
power/consume coolant.
tooltip.biggerreactors.buttons.reactor.w:
§bAuto-Eject Waste
Waste in the core will be ejected as soon as possible.

§bDon't Auto-Eject Waste
§dWaste must be manually ejected!

§bEject Waste Now
Ejects waste from the core.
1000 mB of waste equals 1 ingot.
§8[Shift]: Dump any/all excess waste.
tooltip.biggerreactors.symbols.reactor.c:
§bCase Heat
Heat of the reactor's fuel.
High heat raises fuel usage.
Core heat is transferred to the casing.
Transfer rate is based on the design
of the reactor's interior.
tooltip.biggerreactors.symbols.reactor.f:
§bFuel Heat
Heat of the reactor's casing.
High heat raises energy output
and coolant conversion.
tooltip.biggerreactors.symbols.reactor.c:
§bCoolant Fluid Tank
Case heat will superheat
coolant in this tank.
tooltip.biggerreactors.symbols.reactor.h:
§bHot Fluid Tank
Superheated coolant will
pump into this tank, and
must be piped out via
coolant ports.
tooltip.biggerreactors.symbols.reactor.t:
§bCore Temperature
Temperature inside the reactor core.
Higher temperatures increase fuel
burn-up.
tooltip.biggerreactors.symbols.reactor.f:
§bFuel Burn-up Rate
The rate at which fuel is fissioned
into waste in the core.

§bFuel Reactivity
How heavily irradiated the core is.
Higher levels of radiation reduce
fuel burn-up.
tooltip.biggerreactors.buttons.turbine.a:
§bActivate Turbine
Enables flow of intake fluid to rotor.
Fluid flow will spin up the rotor.

§bDeactivate Turbine
Disables flow of intake fluid to rotor.
The rotor will spin down.
tooltip.biggerreactors.buttons.turbine.c:
§bEngage Coils
Engages the induction coils.
Energy will be extracted from
the rotor and converted to RF.
Energy extraction exerts
drag on the rotor, slowing
it down.

§bDisengage Coils
Disengages the induction coils.
Energy will not be extracted
from the rotor, allowing it
to spin faster.
tooltip.biggerreactors.buttons.turbine.v:
§bVent Overflow Only
Dump excess exhaust fluids.
Excess fluids will be lost if
exhaust fluid tank is full.

§bVent All Exhaust
Dump all exhaust fluids.
The exhaust fluid tank
will not fill.

§bVent Nothing
Preserve all exhaust fluids.
Turbine will slow or halt fluid
intake if exhaust tank is full.
tooltip.biggerreactors.buttons.turbine.f:
§bIncrease Max Flow Rate
Higher flow rates will increase rotor speed.
§8[Shift]: Increase by 10 mB/t.
§8[Ctrl]: Increase by 100 mB/t.
§8[Ctrl + Shift]: Increase by 1000 mB/t.

§bDecrease Max Flow Rate
Lower flow rates will decrease rotor speed.
§8[Shift]: Decrease by 10 mB/t.
§8[Ctrl]: Decrease by 100 mB/t.
§8[Ctrl + Shift]: Decrease by 1000 mB/t.
tooltip.biggerreactors.symbols.turbine.t:
§bTachometer
Rotors perform best at
around 900 or 1800 RPM.
Rotors kept overspeed for
too long may fail.
tooltip.biggerreactors.symbols.turbine.g:
§bFlow Rate Governor
Controls the maximum rate
at which the turbine will
process fluids.
tooltip.biggerreactors.symbols.turbine.o:
§bTurbine Output
Turbines generate energy
via metal induction coils placed
around a spinning rotor.
More (or higher quality) coils
generate energy faster.
tooltip.biggerreactors.symbols.turbine.r:
§bRotor Efficiency
Rotor blades can only capture
so much fluid per blade.
Efficiency drops if the flow
of input raises past capacity.
